case_vignette: A 66-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new skin lesion on his hand. He is concerned because the lesion has grown rapidly over the previous 2 weeks. He endorses traumatizing the area and notes that there was some bleeding. His past medical history is significant for chronic renal failure for which he received a renal transplant 5 years prior, as well as multiple surgeries for skin cancers. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, prednisone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil. Physical exam is notable for a 2 x 2.5 cm nodular lesion of the dorsal hand (Figure A).
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

The bump has grown rapidly over the past 2 weeks, but I haven't had a fever, fatigue, or noticed any insect bites or other signs of infection.

Have you noticed any other symptoms such as redness, warmth, or tenderness around the bump? And have you had any recent exposure to any chemicals, plants, or other substances that could cause a skin reaction?
There's no redness, warmth, or tenderness around the bump, and I haven't been exposed to chemicals, plants, or other substances that could cause a skin reaction.

Great, thank you for the information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask a few more questions to help determine the possible cause of the bump on your hand.

Has the bump changed in size or shape over the past few days? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as a feeling of numbness or tingling in your hand or fingers?

Please let me know the answers to these questions, and I will continue to help you determine the possible cause of the bump on your hand.
The bump has grown rapidly over the past 2 weeks, but I haven't felt any numbness or tingling in my hand or fingers.

Thank you for the information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask a few more questions to help determine the possible cause of the rapidly growing bump on your hand.

Can you tell me more about your medical history? Have you had any previous skin conditions or injuries to your hand? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as itching, burning, or discharge around the bump?

Please let me know the answers to these questions, and I will continue to help you determine the possible cause of the bump on your hand.
I've had multiple surgeries for skin cancers in the past, and I've injured the area that the bump is in now and it did bleed; there's no itching, burning, or discharge.

Thank you for providing that information. Based on your medical history, the bump on your hand could potentially be related to a skin cancer recurrence or a new skin cancer lesion. It's important to have the bump evaluated by a dermatologist to rule out skin cancer and determine the appropriate course of treatment.

I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a dermatologist as soon as possible to have the bump evaluated. In the meantime, you can keep an eye on the bump and monitor its size and shape, as well as any changes in sensation or color in the surrounding skin. If you notice any unexpected changes, such as rapid growth or bleeding, be sure to seek medical attention immediately.

Remember, early detection and treatment of skin cancer can significantly improve outcomes, so it's important to be proactive about monitoring your skin and seeking medical attention if you notice any unusual changes.
